Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
11/27/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
• (3) An agency shall provide the licensee an application
for renewal of the license and document the action not
less than 60 calendar days before the expiration date of
the license. A renewal application must be provided to a
license, regardless of any pending recommendation for
disciplinary action of the license.
One of six open foster home licensing records reviewed did not have documentation
that the applicant received the application within 60 days.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (4) At least 1 adult member of the household must have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
and cardiopulmonary recitation from the American Heart
Association or American Red Cross or other institution
approved by the department.
One of six open foster home licensing records reviewed did not show documentation of
current First Aid/CPR certification.
CPR Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
2

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar thereafter.
Two of eleven updated service plans of foster care/independent living case records
reviewed were late and past the 90 days requirement for the rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/15/2023 Renewal, CAP Approved 9/18/2023
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child’s parents and
the foster parents in the development of service plans
to enable the parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the parents’ and
foster parent’s role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and
review the parent-agency treatment plan with the
parent or parents and foster parents. The agency
must inform the parent or parents and foster parents
that the information in the parent-agency treatment
plan and any other information about the child and the
child’s family is confidential.
Six of eight foster care case records reviewed did not involve the parent/parents, foster
parent in the development of the treatment plans. The treatment plans were late or
missing from the case records.
CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record
• (3) The record must contain all of the following
information:
(g) A photograph taken at least annually.
One of eight foster care case records reviewed did not have an updated photograph.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Reminder to generate and save updated medical passports quarterly. Updated
and signed medical passports were in the file, so there is no
citation. Generating and saving verifies the once per quarter updating.
• FTM’s were conducted but focus should be to ensure they are considered
timely.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance:
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. One CAP
submitted was in response to the 2023 renewal inspection completed on
9/15/2023 and the CAP was approved on 9/28/2023. The agency was cited for 5
violations, Rules 400.12327 (5) (c), 400.12418 (2) (b), 400.12509 (3) (o),
400.12510 (1) (a-d) and Policy FOM 722.08D. There was one repeat violation
during this reporting period.
A special investigation #2023C0000079 was initiated on 3/8/2023. The report was
completed on 8/6/2023, and the CAP was approved on 5/9/2023. The agency
was in non-compliance with Rules 400.12206 (1) and Rule 400. 12503 (2) (e).
The agency is following their CAP.
Special investigation #2024SIC0001400 was initiated on 5/3/2024. The report
was completed 5/15/24 and the CAP was approved on 6/10/2024. The agency
was in violation with Rule 400.12421 (1). The agency continues to follow their
CAP as this rule has not been repeated this reporting period.
4

Chief Administrator Assessment:
The Chief Administrator (CA) discussed the barriers the agency has experienced
over the past year which included continued staffing changes. She reported it took
a considerable time to hire staff, train them, and determine systems that work well
for the team to ensure efficient and quality work. CA reported that it continues to
work on determining those systems and being able to maintain consistency of the
systems through staff changes. She said there are continued systemic factors in
regard to data management to address ISEP. CA reported there has been an
increase on the focus, creating multiple meetings and many email communications
to discuss the KPI data, which focuses the attention away from the work, although
she believes some of the information has been useful in getting closer to meeting
the standards. CA reported she believe human error needs to be considered as a
factor. CA said while the agency utilizes checks and balances to help minimize
errors, it is inevitable that human error will play a factor in not meeting every
standard. However, the agency will do the best they can with the resources they
have.
Financial Overview:
The agency submitted their agency budget and independent audit dated
12//31/2023. No concerns were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews:
The staff were very supportive of the agency, their coworkers, supervisors and the
training they receive. They would not change anything at this time.
Description of Agency Walk Through:
The agency has the space and equipment needed to perform job requirements.
The files are stored securely to prevent unauthorized access
5

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
